contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox City Japan |Name= Kawanishi |JapaneseName= 川西町 |settlement_type= Town |MapImage= Kawanishi in Yamagata Prefecture.png |Region= [[Tōhoku region|Tōhoku]] |Prefecture= [[Yamagata Prefecture|Yamagata]] |District= [[Higashiokitama District, Yamagata|Higashiokitama]] |Area_km2= 166.46 |PopDate= November 2010 |Population= 17,302 |Density_km2= auto |Coords= |LatitudeDegrees = 38 |LatitudeMinutes = 00 |LatitudeSeconds = |LongtitudeDegrees = 140 |LongtitudeMinutes = 03 |LongtitudeSeconds = |Tree= |Flower= |Bird= |SymbolImage= |SymbolDescription= |Mayor= |CityHallPostalCode= |CityHallAddress= |CityHallPhone= |CityHallLink= [http://www.town.kawanishi.yamagata.jp/ Town of Kawanishi] }} {{nihongo|'''Kawanishi'''|川西町|Kawanishi-machi}} is a [[towns of Japan|town]] located in [[Higashiokitama District, Yamagata]], [[Japan]]. The literal meaning of Kawanishi is "west of the river", and the river refers to the [[Mogami River]]. As of November 2010, the town has an estimated [[population]] of 17,302 and a [[population density|density]] of 104 persons per km². The total area is 166.46 km². The town is famous for the large [[dahlia]] garden called ''Kawanishi Dariyaen'' <small>川西ダリヤ園</small> (Kawanishi Dahlia Park), which opens during the [[dahlia]] season (usually August to November). The town also produces the famous ''Yonezawagyu''<small>米沢牛</small> ([[Yonezawa beef]]) since the [[Meiji era]]. Once the nineteenth-century English traveler, writer, and natural historian, [[Isabella Bird]] stayed in the town, and noted the Yonezawa Basin area "as a 'Garden of Eden,' ground that smiles fruitfully, and Arcadia in Asia." "The word 'Arcadia' indicates basically an ideal world and a concept that does not really exist."<ref>http://www.tohokukanko.jp/english/feature/nature.html</ref> ==Geography== The town is located in the southeast of ''Yonezawa Bonchi''<small>米沢盆地</small> (Yonezawa [[Depression (geology)|Basin]]). There are two major rivers, ''Mogamigawa''<small>最上川</small> ([[Mogami River]]) and ''Omonogawa''<small>鬼面川</small> (Omono River), running along the town's borders. Also, there are two minor rivers, ''Inukawa''<small>犬川</small> (Inu river) and ''Kurokawa''<small>黒川</small> (Kuro River), running across the town. The abundance of water makes the town ideal for farming, mostly [[rice]]. ===Adjoining cities and towns=== From the north, following Kawanishi’s border [[clockwise]]: * [[Nagai, Yamagata]] * [[Nanyo, Yamagata]] * [[Takahata, Yamagata]] * [[Yonezawa, Yamagata]] * [[Iide, Yamagata]] ==Transportation== ===Train stations=== * [[East Japan Railway Company|JR East]] **'''[[Yonesaka Line]]''': [[Chūgun Station|Chūgun]] - [[Uzen-Komatsu Station|Uzen-Komatsu]] - [[Inukawa Station|Inukawa]] * [[Yamagata Railway]] **'''[[Flower Nagai Line]]''': [[Nishi-Ōtsuka Station|Nishi-Ōtsuka]] ===Major roads=== * [[Route 113 (Japan)|Route 113]], [[Route 287 (Japan)|Route 287]] ==Film Locations== * [[Warabi no kō]] (2003) * [[Swing Girls]] (2004)- The competition scene filmed particularly at the town's library and Theater complex called Kawanishi-machi Friendly Plaza. ==Notable People from Kawanishi== * [[Hisashi Inoue]]<small>井上ひさし</small> -a leading Japanese [[playwright]] and writer of comic fiction. * Zenshu Sagae<small>寒河江 善秋</small> -a Japanese social activist and writer. ==External links== {{Commons category-inline}} *[http://www.town.kawanishi.yamagata.jp/ The town of Kawanishi official website] {{ja icon}} *[http://www8.plala.or.jp/kawa-kanko/ Official Kawanishi Association of Tourism website] {{ja icon}} *[http://www.town.kawanishi.yamagata.jp/dariya/ Official Kawanishi Dahlia Park website] {{ja icon}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Towns in Yamagata Prefecture]] {{Yamagata-geo-stub}}
